entry.title: Story SSO - troubleshooting Points
entry.content:
A very common scenario: users can log on to SuccessFactors without any problem, but fail to open a Story report. This is caused by failure of SF->Story SSO. 

There are quite a few possible reasons for this. KBA 2912865 ‚Äì [Main KBA] Unable to access Story reports in SuccessFactors already covers most of them in detail. This post is meant as a simpler and add‚Äëon to that KBA, focusing on the checks I do in projects.

1. Use Upgrade Center to activate Story in IAS. The out of box setup is reliable and straigtforward. Avoid customizing too much. 

2. Make sure you use the correct URL. If you‚Äôre using an IAS ‚Äúbackdoor‚Äù URL, make sure you‚Äôre using the new accounts.cloud.sap domain and not the legacy one.

Correct Domain

https://iastenant88.accounts.cloud.sap/saml2/idp/sso?sp=https://www.successfactors.com/ sftenant88&idp=https:// iastenant88.accounts.ondemand.com

Legacy domain (Do not use)

https://iastenant88.accounts.ondemand.com/saml2/idp/sso?sp=https://www.successfactors.com/ sftenant88&idp=https:// iastenant88.accounts.ondemand.com

It is because IAS has undergone common super domain migration. The legacy domain URL will not work for Story SSO.

3. Make sure your browser is set up correctly. Refer to KBA 3039244 - Unable to access Story Reports due to Browser Settings - MS Edge & Google Chrome

4. Make sure SF UDF PERSON_GUID is maintained and replicated to IAS user profile Custom Attribute 1 successfully. This field is configured as Subject Name Identifier as per standard.

5. Make sure the user trying to access Story has the right permission and successfully replicated to Story. Check IPS Job Execution Details.

6. If you as a consultant can access Story successfully, but end users still can‚Äôt access it even with correct browser settings, there‚Äôs a chance the corporate network is blocking SF/Story domains. In that case, ask the customer‚Äôs network team to whitelist SF/Story domains. 

Above 7 points are typically what I checked during implementation when Story SSO is not working. It covers majority of root causes.

entry.title: Re: SAP Personas - table view on mobile
entry.content:
Table on classic webgui application wasn't designed to be used with mobile device, I suppose. 
The number of visible rows in some applications depends on available height of the window and user area. 

In your case, the best option is to play around with "resize()" Scripting API and increase the height of window and user area:

  1. Create onLoad event script for screen where Table is visible:  
    session.findById("wnd[0]").resize(500, 1000, 500, 1000);
  2. Play around with width and height parameters

Not sure how much more visible rows is possible to get but I was able to get 6-8 rows instead of 3 on VA02 app Sales TAB for iPhone.

The only problem here is that if you will increase Height in such way, you will have some extra empty space below. But this seems good trade off.

Best Regards!

entry.title: Re: Custom field has no value help in some screens but ha...
entry.content:
Dear @kostadin_terziev,

What you‚Äôre seeing is a UI-technology limitation, not an issue with your CDS value help

  • Post General Journal Entries is a SAPUI5/Fiori app. For key-user custom fields, SAPUI5 consumes the OData/CDS value help annotations so the value help dialog can be rendered
  • FB60/FB70 even when started from the launchpad are classic transaction apps SAP GUI. Those screens use the SAP GUI F4/search help mechanism, and they do not consume the CDS/OData value help metadata that your Code List based on CDS View field relies on. Result the field can be shown, but the value help popup is not triggered/available. SAP explicitly documents this as a limitation for these apps

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3555532

Summary:

In Public Cloud you can‚Äôt make classic SAP GUI transactions behave like SAPUI5 for key-user CDS-based value helps. So same behavior across all screens is only achievable by standardizing on screens that support the Fiori extensibility/value help framework

Recommended approach:

  • For supplier invoices use Manage Supplier Invoices (F0859) instead of FB60
  • For mass/automated creation use Import Supplier Invoices (F3041) or posting APIs also suggested by SAP

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F0859')/S35

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F3041')/S35

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Implementation Guide: Integrating the UI5 Spreadsheet Importer in a FIORI Application
entry.content:
1.0 Introduction to the UI5 Spreadsheet Importer

The Spreadsheet Importer offers several strategic advantages that make it an invaluable tool for modern FIORI development:

  • Seamless Data Integration: It allows applications to read and process Excel files directly on the front end, eliminating cumbersome manual data entry and reducing the risk of errors. A key benefit is its independence from the specific backend OData service implementation, making it compatible with both Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) and ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) scenarios.
  • Out-of-the-Box Functionality: The component supports standard spreadsheet formats (.xls and .xlsx) and utilizes the robust SheetJS library to parse file data within the browser. This avoids sending large binary files to the backend. It automatically converts spreadsheet data into the required OData format for seamless communication with your SAP system.
  • Productivity Improvements: With an intuitive interface and straightforward configuration, the component requires minimal coding effort from developers. It supports every type of OData service (SEGW, RAP, and CAP), accelerating development cycles and improving the efficiency of business processes.
  • Community and Security: As a well-regarded open-source tool, the Spreadsheet Importer benefits from strong community support on GitHub, ensuring it is well-documented and continuously improved. It maintains high security standards with no known vulnerabilities reported in recent audits.
  • Proven Track Record: The component has been successfully adopted by numerous SAP developers across the ecosystem. Its reliability is underscored by its implementation as an extension in a standard SAP banking application, proving its scalability for mission-critical enterprise environments.

Before beginning implementation, it is essential to understand the specific licensing and versioning requirements associated with this component.

2.0 Critical Prerequisites: Licensing and Version Control

Adhering to the correct licensing and versioning requirements is a critical prerequisite for any implementation. This ensures full compliance with open-source software policies and guarantees the long-term stability and supportability of your application.

The component is available under two distinct licensing models, and it is mandatory to use the approved version.

Version

Licensing and Usage Details

Version 1.x (e.g., 1.7.4)

Licensed under Apache 2.0. This is the free-of-charge Community Edition. 

Version 2.0.0 and above

Requires a commercial license.

Mandatory Version

To ensure consistency and compliance across all projects, a specific version has been mandated for all development.

The required and approved version for all implementations we have used in this article - 1.7.4.

With these prerequisites established, we can proceed with the technical steps required for integration.

3.0 Step-by-Step Implementation Workflow

Integrating the Spreadsheet Importer into a FIORI Element application involves five core steps. This workflow covers modifications to the UI manifest, the implementation of controller logic, and the necessary configurations for the project's dependencies and build scripts.

3.1 Step 1: Add the Custom "Excel Upload" Action

The first step is to add a custom action button to the List Report page. This is accomplished by extending the view controller within the application's manifest.json file.

Add the following "extends" block to your manifest.json:

"extends": {
  "extensions": {
    "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
      "sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ListReport.view.ListReport": {
        "controllerName": "<yournamespace>.doerategrp.ext.controller.ListReportExt",
        "sap.ui.generic.app": {
          "rateGroupSet": {
            "EntitySet": "rateGroupSet",
            "Actions": {
              "excelUpload": {
                "id": "excelUploadButton",
                "text": "Excel Upload",
                "press": "openSpreadsheetUpload",
                "requiresSelection": false
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

This configuration achieves the following:

  • "controllerName": Specifies the custom controller extension file that will contain the button's logic.
  • "id": "excelUploadButton": Assigns a unique ID to the new button control.
  • "text": "Excel Upload": Sets the display text for the button on the UI.
  • "press": "openSpreadsheetUpload": Defines the event handler function that will be called when the user clicks the button.

Pro-Tip: The controllerName (com.deere.doerategrp.ext.controller.ListReportExt) and the EntitySet key (rateGroupSet) are specific to this example. You must update these values to match your project's namespace and the target OData EntitySet for the table you are extending.

3.2 Step 2: Configure the Controller Extension (ListReportExt.controller.js)

Next, you must implement the openSpreadsheetUpload event handler defined in the manifest.json. This function will reside in your custom controller extension file, ListReportExt.controller.js.

Use the following code to implement the function. It is important to only use the openSpreadsheetUpload function as provided; other methods mentioned in the source documentation, such as attachChangeBeforeCreate and attachUploadButtonPress, may not be usable and should be ignored.

sap.ui.define(["sap/m/MessageToast"], function (MessageToast) {
    'use strict';

    return {
        openSpreadsheetUpload: async function (oEvent) {
            MessageToast.show("Spreadsheet upload initiated.");
            this.getView().setBusyIndicatorDelay(0);
            this.getView().setBusy(true);
            this.spreadsheetUpload = await this.getView()
                .getController()
                .getOwnerComponent()
                .createComponent({
                    usage: "spreadsheetImporter",
                    async: true,
                    componentData: {
                        context: this,
                        columns: ['shippingPoint', 'destRegion', 'matFrtGroup', 'shippingType', 'validFrom', 'validTo', 'rateGroups'],
                        mandatoryFields: ['shippingPoint', 'destRegion', 'matFrtGroup', 'shippingType', 'validFrom'],
                        showBackendErrorMessages: true,
                        continueOnError: true,
                        useTableSelector: false,
                        addArrayToMessages: true,
                        strict: true,
                        tableId: "<yournamespace>.doerategrp::sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ListReport.view.ListReport::rateGroupSet--responsiveTable",
                        sampleData: [{
                            shippingPoint: 'HX1C',
                            destRegion: 'MD',
                            matFrtGroup: 'OMFR0005',
                            shippingType: '10',
                            validFrom: '9999-12-31',
                            validTo: '9999-12-31',
                            rateGroups: 'RT002'
                        }]
                    },
                });
            
            await this.spreadsheetUpload.triggerInitContext();
            
            this.spreadsheetUpload.openSpreadsheetUploadDialog();
            this.getView().setBusy(false);
        }
    };
});

The componentData object is used to configure the importer's behavior. Key parameters include:

  • columns: An array of strings defining the OData property names that correspond to the columns in the spreadsheet.
  • mandatoryFields: An array of strings specifying which columns must contain data for a row to be considered valid.
  • tableId: The full ID of the target table in the List Report where the data will be inserted. You can find this ID by inspecting the table element in your browser's developer tools. It must be the complete, stable ID for the target sap.m.Table or sap.ui.table.Table.
  • sampleData: Provides a sample data row that can be used to generate a downloadable template for users.

3.3 Step 3: Define Component Dependencies in manifest.json

The application manifest must be updated to declare its dependency on the Spreadsheet Importer component. This allows the UI5 framework to locate and load the component's resources.

Add the following componentUsages and resourceRoots configurations to your manifest.json:

"componentUsages": {
  "spreadsheetImporter": {
    "name": "cc.spreadsheetimporter.v1_7_4"
  }
},
"resourceRoots": {
  "cc.spreadsheetimporter.v1_7_4": "./thirdparty/customcontrol/spreadsheetimporter/v1_7_4"
},

The key spreadsheetImporter is a local alias defined for this component's usage. This alias is what you will use to reference the component within your application's controller code. The resourceRoots path shown here is configured for local development and testing within SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). This path will be adjusted for deployment to an on-premise system, as detailed later in this guide.

3.4 Step 4: Update Project Dependencies in package.json

To enable local development, testing, and builds, the Spreadsheet Importer component must be added as a dependency in the project's package.json file.

Add the following line to the dependencies section of your package.json:

// In your package.json, add the following to "dependencies":
"ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter": "^1.7.4"

3.5 Step 5: Configure the Build Script

The final configuration step is to modify the build script in package.json to ensure that all dependencies, including the custom component, are correctly processed during the build.

Add the --all flag to the "build" script command:

"build": "ui5 build --config=ui5.yaml --all --clean-dest --dest dist",

With the application now fully configured for local development and testing, the next crucial phase is to prepare it for deployment to a production-like on-premise environment, which follows a specific, centralized strategy.

4.0 On-Premise Deployment Strategy

For on-premise landscapes, a centralized deployment model for the Spreadsheet Importer component is mandatory. This model leverages a single, pre-existing instance of the component that has been deployed centrally as a BSP application. This simplifies individual application deployments, as you only need to reference this central component rather than deploying it with every application.

4.1 Understanding the resourceRoots Path for Deployed Applications

The resourceRoots path in the manifest.json file is environment-specific. The path used for local development in BAS is different from the one required for a deployed application running on the FIORI Launchpad.

Environment

resourceRoots Path in manifest.json

BAS / Local Development

"./thirdparty/customcontrol/spreadsheetimporter/v1_7_4"

On-Premise Deployment

"./thirdparty/customcontrol/spreadsheetimporter/v1_7_4"

The path for the deployed application points to a centrally available BSP application named ZVA0_EXL_UPD. This BSP application already contains the approved version 1.7.4 of the Spreadsheet Importer component, making it available to all other FIORI applications on the same system.

4.2 Recommended Deployment Configuration for Consistency

To avoid manually changing the resourceRoots path in manifest.json before each deployment, the recommended best practice is to update the build configuration. By excluding certain development-only files from the deployment package, you can maintain a single, consistent manifest.json for both local and deployed environments.

Update your ui5-deploy.yaml file to exclude TypeScript (.ts, .ts.map) and JavaScript map (.js.map) files from the deployment artifact.

- name: deploy-to-abap
  afterTask: generateCachebusterInfo
  configuration:
    target:
      # ... target system details
    app:
      # ... application details
    exclude:
      - /test/
      - .*\.ts
      - .*\.ts.map
      - .*\.js.map

This approach is critical for robust development and deployment pipelines, as it eliminates the need for error-prone manual modifications to the manifest.json file between environments. The local resourceRoots path is automatically ignored during deployment, and the relative path to the central BSP is correctly resolved when the application runs on the FIORI Launchpad.

5.0 Troubleshooting and Known Issues

While the integration process is generally straightforward, developers should be aware of a known issue that may occur during the deployment from SAP Business Application Studio to an on-premise system.

When deploying an application that uses the Spreadsheet Importer component, the deployment process in BAS may report a failure. However, in most cases, the BSP application is still created or updated successfully in the backend ABAP system. This behavior is a known open issue that has been reported to SAP.

For more details on this issue, please refer to the SAP Community discussion: Error when deploying UI5 app (sapui5 library/component used in application)

If you encounter this error, verify the status of the BSP application directly in the backend system before attempting to redeploy.

6.0 Final Validation

The final step is to verify that the Spreadsheet Importer component is fully functional in the target environment.

After a successful deployment, launch your application from the SAP FIORI Launchpad. You should see the "Excel Upload" button on the List Report page. Clicking this button should open the spreadsheet import dialog, confirming that the integration was successful and is ready for users to begin the data import process.

7.0 Appendix: Key Resources

For further information, detailed documentation, and community support, please refer to the following resources:

  • Official GitHub Repository: ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter
  • Live Demo Launchpad: Spreadsheet Importer Live Demo
  • NPM Package: ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter
  • Yeoman Generator: generator-ui5-cc-spreadsheetimporter
  • Official Documentation: Spreadsheet Importer Docs
  • Example Applications: Code Samples
  • wdi5 Tests: Test Examples

entry.title: Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Do you want to see more content like this? Please live a Kudos!

Introduction

Resource Orchestration is a cloud-based scheduling tool in SAP Digital Manufacturing that helps production supervisors stay in control of shop floor execution. It provides a clear overview of operations, resource workloads, and current production status, while automatically balancing work across available resources.

With the Real-Time Monitor, supervisors can quickly respond to changes in production, follow operation schedules and order execution as they happen, identify delays or issues early, and track order progress throughout the shift. This gives supervisors the visibility and flexibility needed to keep production running smoothly and on plan.

Learn below how a Production Supervisor can leverage Resource Orchestration Real-Time Monitor for enhanced scheduling and monitoring in 6 simple steps.

Learn more at Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Step 1: Starting the Day with Real-Time Visibility

At the start of his day, the production supervisor, opens the Real-Time Monitoring View in SAP Digital Manufacturing.
This view gives him a live picture of what is happening on the shop floor right now.

From a single screen, Eliam can see:

  • Which operations are running, completed, or waiting

  • The current progress of each order

  • The status of individual shop floor controls (SFCs)

This helps him understand the current situation before taking any action.

Step 2: Dispatching Pending Operations

As the production supervisor reviews the list, he notices that some operations are still waiting to be dispatched.
If these stay unassigned, production could slow down.

He selects the pending operations and assigns them to available resources that are ready to work.
With just a few actions, the operations are dispatched and execution continues without interruption.

Step 3: Preventing Backlogs Before They Happen

Next, the production supervisor focuses on operations that are close to falling behind plan.

He opens the details of these operations and checks:

  • The related SFCs

  • Their current execution status

  • Where time is being spent

Based on this information, production supervisor adjusts the plan to keep work moving forward and avoid creating a backlog.

Learn more at Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Step 4: Increasing Throughput by Adjusting Labor

To further speed things up, the production supervisor checks the current labor shift plan.

He sees that additional capacity is needed later in the day.
Instead of waiting for delays to occur, he adds more workers to the next shift.

This increases throughput and keeps production aligned with demand.

Step 5: Ensuring the Right Skills Are in Place

Production supervisor then reviews workforce information to make sure execution matches the plan.

He checks:

  • Clock-in and attendance status

  • Worker skills

  • Current assignments

  • Time log entries

This ensures that each operation is performed by someone with the right skills at the right time.

Step 6: Staying in Control Throughout the Shift

Throughout the day, production supervisor keeps the Real-Time Monitoring View open.

As conditions change, he can:

  • Track order progress as it happens

  • Spot delays early

  • Adjust resources or labor immediately

This allows him to stay in control of shop floor execution and keep production running smoothly.

Summary

With Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing, supervisors can:

  • See what is happening on the shop floor right now

  • Act immediately when issues appear

  • Adjust resources and labor without delay

  • Keep production on track throughout the shift

This step-by-step flow shows how supervisors can move from visibility to action, all within a single view.

Learn more at Real-Time Operations Monitoring in SAP Digital Manufacturing.

Do you want to see more content like this? Please live a Kudos!

If you have any questions, please check SAP Community Q&A Area, or comment down below.

Thanks,
Manoel Costa

entry.title: Re: Personas flavor across create, change, display
entry.content:
Hi, 

All SAP Screen Personas changes saved for combination of Transaction/Program/ScreenNumber and Control ID. 
If all this is similar between transactions then there is way to copy one prepared Flavor to other transactions (application IDs) link.

Looking to FMZ1, FMZ2 and FMZ3, I see that Details screen looks the same and Flavors can be copied with no issues to apply changes. 

The only problem you could experience is that Toolbar has different set of buttons between transactions and also Initial screen is different (there are different fields on FMZ1 comparing to ...2/3).

So maybe the way is to create Flavor for FMZ2 and then to copy it to FMZ1 and FMZ2. Then update Initial Screen of FMZ1.

Since SP20 there is an option to copy Flavor to Flavor (if you have to update Flavor, then you can copy it to already existing). However in case described above, you will have to redo chances of initials screen of FMZ1 again.

Best Regards!

entry.title: Re: Requirement for OR-based Multiple Maintenance Interva...
entry.content:
@mohit9210 ,

You need to create separate Maintenance Plans because the conditions which you have listed out can be assigned at header level not item level.

1. Create the separate Plan for each condition

2. Assign an item and Task list

3. Schedule

You cannot use strategy plan because you want to use OR condition at operation level. In strategy plan you can use only one cycle (either time or counter).

Vaibhav Mishra

entry.title: Re: Deletion button disabled / greyed out in CL02 when us...
entry.content:
Dear @arturo_suarez,

Your symptoms are described exactly in the SAP Note below BUT for NOT Public Cloud:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002087043

What option would normally control CL141?

Message CL141 literally tells you the fix either don‚Äôt use a change number or activate ECM for that class type in customizing O1CL / Maintain Object Types and Class Types, so the option you‚Äôre looking for is in O1CL NOT available in Public Cloud

SAP has an official Public Cloud Note that states: Maintain Object Types and Class Types (O1CL) is not currently available as a Configuration Activity in S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3670709

Summary:

  • CL141 is telling you turn on ECM for this class type in O1CL
  • SAP Note says O1CL is not available as a configuration activity in Public Cloud
    Therefore you won‚Äôt be able to enable it yourself in Public Cloud and CL02/CL6K will continue to ignore the change number for that class type and disable certain actions when in ECM mode

Practical options:

  1. Delete the characteristic assignment without a change number
  2. If you need valid-from ECM on VC classes log an SAP incydent but this is typically treated as not customer-configurable in Public Cloud
  3. Submit a feature request by following the SAP Note: https://me.sap.com/notes/2963059

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: ILOData (Interactive Local Offline OData)
entry.content:
ILOData (Interactive Local Offline OData)

Overview

ILOData (Interactive Local Offline OData) is a command-line utility designed for developers to inspect, query, and manage offline OData databases on their local machine. Acting as an offline OData client, ILOData allows testing and debugging of back-end data without requiring a running application or connected device. It provides direct access to the locally stored offline database, enabling developers to execute OData requests, queries, flushes, and refreshes against the offline store. The tool is particularly useful for understanding the structure and content of MDK-generated UDB files, troubleshooting synchronization issues, and validating data handling within the client application. By leveraging ILOData, developers can efficiently analyze and manipulate offline data in a secure and controlled environment, accelerating the development and debugging workflow.

 

Requirements

You need a branded client to access the UDB files. To make the UDB files readable (unencrypted), set SecureDatabaseEncryptionKey to false in the BrandedSettings.json file.

 


Access UDB files

Refer to SAP Note https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/0003041428

 

UDB files

Once you have followed the SAP Note above, you should see two files: DestinationName.rq.udb and DestinationName.udb. Both files must exist in the same folder on your machine.

Open the iOS folder, then the macos subfolder. The ZIP file contains the ilodata command-line tool. To access the SAP Offline OData tools, unzip the zip file.


Note: Lower versions of the ilodata command line tool cannot be used to open UDB files created with the latest MDK build.

 

Getting Started with Ilodata

There are two ways to start working with the ilodata command line tool:

  1. Place the ilodata command line tool directly in the folder containing your UDB files.
  2. Alternatively, move the ilodata command line tool to ‚Äò/usr/local/bin‚Äô and assign it ‚Äòchmod 755 ilodata‚Äô permissions.

The second method allows the user to execute the ilodata binary from the terminal without needing to know its exact location.

For Windows, this can be done by copying the binary into the user‚Äôs AppData folder (Optionally it can be copied to another location, however, you need to update the PATH environment variable).

 

Access Ilodata command line tools

The recommended source for obtaining the ilodata command-line tools (ilodata binaries) is the SAP Marketplace. You can download the MDK client(MDKCLNT.zip) to your local machine. After downloading, unzip the folder, and you will find a tools directory within the MDK Client folder.

Navigate to the ‚Äòilodata‚Äô folder and select the application corresponding to your operating system, either iOS or Android.

 

Read the UDB files

To read the UDB files, open a terminal in the folder where the files are stored. Depending on the location of the ILOData binary, execute one of the following commands:

  1. On macOS, if the ILOData binary is located in the same directory as the UDB files
./ilodata store_name=DEST_SAM2505_PPROP store_key=MDK

        2.  If the ILOData binary is stored in ‚Äò/usr/local/bin‚Äô

ilodata store_name=DEST_SAM2505_PPROP store_key=MDK

Note: On Windows, the folder containing ilodata must be included in the user‚Äôs PATH environment variable (or alternatively, it can be stored in ‚Äò/usr/local/bin‚Äô).  On macOS, ensure that the folder has the appropriate permissions set via chmod.

After successfully opening the UDB files, you will notice that two additional files have been added to the 2505 folder.

Once the command prompt is launched, the prompt will appear as shown below:

Once the ILoData > prompt is displayed, you can execute standard HTTP commands to interact with the database, including GET, POST, PATCH, and DELETE, similar to how you would interact with an HTTP OData service.

Below are examples of ILOData CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations:

 

Fetching (GET) Data

One of the main functions of ILOData is to retrieve data from a UDB. It allows developers to verify that client transactions are working correctly.

Examples:

  • GET MyWorkOrderHeaders
    Returns a list of work order records in JSON format, with the data presented as an array of objects.
  • GET MyWorkOrderHeaders('4448540')
    Returns the data of a single work order (ID: 4448540) as a JSON object.
  • GET MyWorkOrderHeaders/$count
    Returns the total number of records in the MyWorkOrderHeaders entity.

 

Tip: On macOS, you can clear the command prompt by pressing ‚ÄòCommand + K‚Äô

Note: For more information on OData syntax and usage, visit: https://www.odata.org/documentation/odata-version-2-0/uri-conventions/

 

Creating Data

Sometimes, user may need to add new data to a UDB, for example, for testing. This can be done using a POST request. A standard POST request includes a payload along with the URI, and ILOData treats any key-value pairs after the URI as part of this payload.

Examples:

  • POST MyNotificationHeaders
    Creates a new notification record with no data. ILOData returns the new record in JSON format, with all fields initially set to null.
  • POST MyNotificationHeaders Priority=2 MainWorkCenterPlant=1000 NotificationDescription="Test Notification"
    Creates a new notification record with some fields populated.

In both cases, the key field NotificationNumber is left empty. ILOData accepts empty key fields, which may be required by backend business logic. Locally created records can be accessed using GET, PATCH, or DELETE commands via the returned record‚Äôs read link.

  • GET MyNotificationHeaders(lodata_sys_eid=X'2AB80DE2597E49EFB832B0E39B38CD2400000000')
    Use this command to access newly injected data. Replace lodata_sys_eid with the correct value for the record you want to retrieve.

Note : Normally, the read link uses specific Notification Number. For example : MyNotificationHeaders(‚Äò10000025‚Äô)

 

Updating Data

Altering existing records is similar to creating new records. The HTTP verb used for updating records is PATCH. Like POST, a PATCH request includes a payload, which contains key-value pairs for the properties that need to be updated on a given entity.

Example:

  • PATCH MyNotificationHeaders('10000035') Priority=3 NotificationType=M1

This command updates the specified properties (Priority and NotificationType) of the existing notification record with ID 10000035.

 

Deleting Data

The DELETE verb is used to remove records from the UDB. Unlike POST and PATCH, an HTTP DELETE request does not include a payload and functions similarly to a GET request in structure.

Example:

  • DELETE MyNotificationHeaders('10000035')

Use this command to delete a single entity in ILOData.

Note:

  • ILOData can delete only one entity at a time.
  • DELETE requests cannot be used together with filter queries.

 

Further Reading

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MOBILE_PLATFORM_SDK_31/42dc90f1e1ed45d9aafad60c80646d10/e39146a34d964a7da0493d63223cf7e9.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

https://www.odata.org/documentation/odata-version-2-0/uri-conventions/

entry.title: SAP BTP - APIM - Demystified: Designing a Single API Proxy with Dynamic Routing for Multiple Targets
entry.content:
Introduction

In modern enterprise landscapes, APIs are no longer simple pass-through interfaces; they are strategic assets that must support multiple backends, environment segregation, multi-tenant scenarios, and dynamic routing‚Äîall while remaining secure, observable, and maintainable.

Within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP API Management plays a critical role as the security and governance layer for backend systems like SAP Integration Suite (CPI), S/4HANA, ECC, Fieldglass, Concur, and various external applications.

In this blog, I present a common enterprise requirement: designing a single security layer that acts as a shield for SAP CPI, handling access control, host protection, and traffic governance. I will demonstrate how to build a single API Proxy with dynamic routing capabilities, allowing multiple iFlow endpoints to be managed through one centralized entry point.

This approach eliminates the need for hundreds of individual proxies, keeps the APIM cockpit organized, and significantly simplifies monitoring. Whether you are a beginner following the step-by-step visuals or a senior consultant jumping straight to the "Checkmate" strategy at the end, this guide is designed for all levels of expertise.

üóùÔ∏è The check-mate secret will be revealed at the end.üóùÔ∏è

To illustrate the introduction, please check the image below:

Figure 1 - Integration Prespective

Summary of the image:

  1. Consumer ‚Üí calls ‚Üí API Proxy (in SAP APIM)
  2. API Proxy (Apply Policies) ‚Üí forwards to ‚Üí API Provider (SAP CPI- Multiples Iflows from the SAP package)
  3. SAP CPI  ‚Üí processes logic ‚Üí Any Backend ( SAP on-prem/SAP on-cloud/External App)

Let‚Äôs move forward together and break down the concepts step by step.

Before we get hands-on, let‚Äôs take a short theoretical detour to clearly understand what each object is responsible for.

What is an API Proxy ?

Think of the proxy as a Security and Governance Layer. While the backend provides the data, the proxy provides

  • Security: Enforces OAuth, Basic Authentication, API Keys Header, or SQL injection protection.
  • Traffic Control: Sets rate limits (e.g., 100 calls per minute) to protect your backend from crashing.
  • Transformation: Converts data formats (e.g., SOAP to REST or XML to JSON) without changing the backend code.
  • Analytics: Tracks who is using the API and how often.

What is API provider ?

An API Provider is a centralized configuration in SAP APIM that defines the connection details, authentication, and location of a backend system, such as SAP S/4HANA or SAP CPI.

Instead of hard-coding URLs into every individual proxy, you create a Provider once to act as a reusable gateway to that system‚Äôs entire service catalog.

This "clean" approach allows you to automatically discover services and update backend settings in one single place without breaking your existing API proxies.

Can SAP CPI be an API Provider?

Yes, absolutely. In fact, this is a very common "best practice" in the SAP Integration Suite.

  • SAP CPI (Cloud Integration) is the Execution Engine: It handles the complex logic, data mapping, and connecting to multiple systems.
  • SAP APIM is the Governance Layer: It handles the exposure of that CPI flow to the outside world

From Concept to Implementation

We‚Äôve talked the talk ‚Äî now it‚Äôs time to make these APIs working.

Our Mission Together

Build a Multi-Target Mega-Proxy:

  • One front door (API Proxy)
  • Smart enough to check the visitor‚Äôs ‚ÄúID‚Äù (headers, basic authentication, mask host)
  • Routes requests dynamically to different CPI iFlows based on the HTTP path

I'm going to cross together with you in phases:

  • Phase 1: The "Secret Agents" (Setting up Providers)
  • Phase 2: The "Master Architect" (Creating the Proxy)
  • Phase 3: The "Split Personality" (Adding the Second Target)
  • Phase 4: The "The Routing Gate for Heaven" (Time to setup the routing mechanism)
  • Phase 5: The "Dangerous Security Zone" (Applying the Shields)

Phase 1: The "Secret Agents" (Setting up Providers)

Before we build the bridge, we need to know where the islands are.

  1. Go to your APIM Portal and hit the Configure icon (the little gears).

  2. Create your first Agent (API Provider): Let‚Äôs call it SAPCPI.

    1.  

      Type: Choose Cloud Integration.
    2. Host: Paste your CPI tenant runtime URL (leave out the https:// - just the hostname).

  3. Save & Test: Click that "Test Connection" button. If it turns green, you‚Äôre a genius. If it turns yellow HTTP 400, you as CPI developer know the reason, the connection is working don't worry.

Figure 2 - API Provider - SAP CPI Configured

Phase 2: The "Master Architect" (Creating the Proxy)

Now, let's build the Proxy that will rule them all, as you can see API proxy can be generated with API provider, API Proxy or URL. To keep very organized and clean governance, use API Provider or API proxy as clone the URL I don't recommend, just for POC that's ok.

  1. Develop ‚Üí APIs ‚Üí Create
  2. The Choice: Select API Provider.
    Pick SAPCPI. 
  3. URL: /
  4. The Name (My recommendation, use the same CPI Package name as reference): Call it PackageSAPSCNBlog.
  5. Host alias: <hostname.your.sap.apim>
  6. API base path ( you can add what ever you want, just as suggestion): /sapcpi/

Figure 3 - Creating the proxy with API provider

Phase 3: The "Split Personality" (Adding the Second Target)

By default, your proxy only knows about CPI. Let's give it a second destination.

  1. Open your new Proxy and go to the Target Endpoints tab.
  2. Click the + (Add) button.
  3. Name it (I recomend the name of Iflow to mantain organized): .<IflowName>

  4. The Magic Link: provide the path generate in SAP CPI, in this case /http/cpi/IflowA.

    • Now your Proxy has two exits, but it doesn't know which one to use yet!

Figure 3 - Create TargetEndpoint

After you generate the target endpoints, you are going to see something like this:

Figure 4 - Multiples Target Endpoints

Phase 4: The "The Routing Gate for Heaven (Time to setup the routing mechanism)

  1. The Choice: ProxyEndPoint
  2. Add the routing rules based on path of SAP CPI endpoint sample based on this blog
    1. IflowA -  proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowA"
    2. IflowB  - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowB"
    3. IflowC - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowC"
    4. IflowD -  proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowD"
    5. IflowE -   proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowE"
    6.  
  3. In this point you can delete the router - default

Figure 5 - Multiples Variable Runtime - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath

Phase 5: The "Dangerous Security Zone" (Applying the Shields - Policies)

To solve the Chess Puzzle of APIM, you have to understand the "Timeline" of a request. A single API call is like a round-trip train journey. The request goes in through the Proxy and out to the Target, then the response comes back from the Target and out through the Proxy.

The PreFlow and PostFlow are the "Stations" where you can plug in your policies.

Proxy Endpoint (The Front Door)

This is where the client (Postman, Mobile App) interacts with APIM.

  • PreFlow: This happens first. It is the best place for Security (API Key, OAuth) and Spike Arrest. If the "visitor" is dangerous, you kick them out here before they waste any more of your system's energy.
  • PostFlow: This happens last, just before the response is sent back to the client. It‚Äôs perfect for Logging or clean-up.

Target Endpoint (The Back Door)

This is where APIM interacts with your backend.

  • PreFlow: This happens right before the request hits your backend. It is the best place for Transformation (adding a specific header the backend needs) or URL Rewriting.
  • PostFlow: This happens right after the backend responds but before it goes back to the Proxy. This is where you might Format JSON or remove sensitive backend headers.

So in the Proxy Endpoint - Preflow I added some security and custom messages replay as you can see in the image below:

Figure 6 - Security Policies - Proxy Endpoing Pre-flow

These are basic policies; for your project, you could add Spike Arrest, OAuth2 validation, and Credential Buffering, but since the focus isn't on complex policies right now, let's stick to the foundational ones.

  1. Step 1: Java script check header
  2. Step 2: Fault custom message response
  3. Step 3: Standard Basic Authentication - Here you need to change the XML from encode to decode
  4. Step 4:Java script security header
  5. Step5: Java script check credentials
  6. Step 6: Fault custom message response - In case of user/pass is empty or different from API Provider - SAP CPI
  7. Step 7: Java Script Set host

In case that you want custom the Fault message, because the standard one it's really technical and if you create something custom will helps more your consumers.

Figure 7 - Custom replay Fault exception

  • Step 2: Fault custom message response
<RaiseFault continueOnError="false"
            enabled="true"
            xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">

    <FaultResponse>
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
            </Headers>

            <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
              "Error": "HTTP 500 - Internal Server Error",
              "Detail": "(Basic Authtentication - User/Password) is required to access this API."
            }
            </Payload>

            <StatusCode>500</StatusCode>
            <ReasonPhrase>Internal Server Error</ReasonPhrase>
        </Set>
    </FaultResponse>

    <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>

</RaiseFault>
  • Step 6: Fault custom message response - In case of user/pass is empty or different from API Provider - SAP CPI
<RaiseFault continueOnError="false" enabled="true"
            xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">

    <FaultResponse>
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
            </Headers>
            <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
              "error": "HTTP 401 Unauthorized",
              "message": "Invalid username or password.The credentials can not be empty value."
            }
            </Payload>
            <StatusCode>401</StatusCode>
            <ReasonPhrase>Unauthorized</ReasonPhrase>
        </Set>
    </FaultResponse>
</RaiseFault>

Full java script - Main.js - I decide create in this way to also keep organized and centralized all functions in one place instead of create one java script per function.

//Check the Check Header
function handleSecurityHeader() {
var authHeader = context.getVariable("request.header.Authorization");

if (!authHeader) {
    context.setVariable("auth.header.missing", true);
} else {
    context.setVariable("auth.header.missing", false);
}
}

//Validation of user/pass
function handleCredentialCheck() {

var user = context.getVariable("basic.username");
var pass = context.getVariable("basic.password");

// DEBUG
context.setVariable("username", user);
context.setVariable("pass", pass);

if (!user || !pass) {
    context.setVariable("auth.failed", true);
} else if (user !== "<SAP CPI USER PROVIDED>" || pass !== "<SAP CPI PASSWORD PROVIDED>") {
    context.setVariable("auth.failed", false);
}
}

//Mask Address
function handleResponseMasking() {
    var rc = context.getVariable("response.content");
    
    if (rc) {
        var targetHost = context.getVariable("target.host");
        var proxyHost = context.getVariable("proxy.host");
        var targetBase = context.getVariable("target.basepath");
        var proxyBase = context.getVariable("proxy.basepath");

        var maskedResponse = rc;

        // Mask the Hostname
        if (targetHost && proxyHost) {
            // 'g' means global (replace all), 'i' means case-insensitive
            var hostRegex = new RegExp(targetHost.toString(), 'gi');
            maskedResponse = maskedResponse.replace(hostRegex, proxyHost.toString());
        }

        // Mask the Base Path
        if (targetBase && proxyBase) {
            var baseRegex = new RegExp(targetBase.toString(), 'gi');
            maskedResponse = maskedResponse.replace(baseRegex, proxyBase.toString());
        } 

        // Update the response content and the custom variable
        context.setVariable("target.host",maskedResponse)
        context.setVariable("response.content", maskedResponse);
        context.setVariable("masked.targeturl", maskedResponse);
    }
}

//Routing mechanism
function RoutingCpiEndpoint() {
    
var suffix = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
if (suffix == null) {
    suffix = "";
}

var targetBase = "<SAP CPI ADDRESS>";

// Use the + operator for compatibility
var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + suffix.toString();

// Set it back to a context variable so the target can use it
context.setVariable("target.url", finalUrl);

}

 //Sets the proxy host in the proxyendpoint preflow so that it can be used later on
function setProxyHost(){
  var host = context.proxyRequest.headers['host'];
  context.setVariable("apim.proxyHost", host);
}

The visual with this organization, the fact you also will create the Main.js, you need to generate the others java scripts, as suggestion create with name convention JS-Exe(function)

Figure 8 - JavaScript Main and Java Script excetion

After that you can click in Java script in the Policy and add in the steps, but how to configure the XML ? Check below:

<IncludeURL>jsc://JS-Main.js</IncludeURL> - Include the JS-Main.js
<ResourceURL>jsc://JS-ExehandleSecurityHeader.js</ResourceURL> - Include the Java Script with function only

If APIM is the "Intelligent Front Door" of your building, then SAP CPI (Cloud Integration) is the "Kitchen" where the real magic (and sometimes the mess) happens.

While APIM is outside checking IDs and looking cool, CPI is in the back wearing an apron, chopping data into pieces, and trying to make sure the S/4HANA "steak" is served exactly the way the client's "mobile app" wants it. üòÇü§£

The SAP CPI perspective, a package represents ( Product ) inside de product contains the services A,B,C,D,E via API as you can see below:

Figure 9 - SAP CPI Packages and Iflows

  1. IflowA -  https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowA
  2. IflowB  - https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowB
  3. IflowC - https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowC
  4. IflowD -  https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowD
  5. IflowE -  https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowE

Ok, you already setup the API Management, Endpoint, Add routing, Policies, generate SAP CPI package, Iflows, deploy those iflow now we are ready to test ? 

I followed the SAP Help guide step by step SAP Help enable-dynamic-routing. I was ready for glory.

Test Phase:

Take the endpoint generated in API management concatenate with the respective path of the iflow that must be called and that's it, use the post man as source for test proposal.

  • SAP APIM: https://<yourinstance>apimanagement.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/sapcpi/
  • SAP CPI:https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowA
  • EndURL:https://<yourinstance>apimanagement.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/sapcpi/http/cpi/IflowA

Uhu, let's go postman !!!

Figure 10 - HTTP 404

Instead, I was met with the cold, hard stare of a 404 ‚Äì Not Found.

Is the documentation wrong? ‚ùå
Is the API broken? ‚ùå

We have simply entered the ‚Äúchess puzzle‚Äù phase of dynamic routing. Don‚Äôt worry ‚Äî we are in this together.

The Final Move: A 'Checkmate' Strategy for Polishing Your API Proxy - The Secret.

In the picture below I'm representing all the topics that we already discuss, if you are tunned, you could see the magic inside the java script JS-Main.js, if not you will see now in the steps below.

Figure 11 - Each endpoint contains Target Endpoint Policy that must be configured with java script in inbound message

The SAP APIM management it self in case of Proxy with API Provider is not able to concatenate automatic the hostname of API provider with the specific PATH URL from the back end system in case of multiple routing mechanism based on path, for it you must use the Java script, that reads the variables in runtime and do this activity, without it always will generate HTTP 404.

In case that you create the API Proxy for URL, yes, he can route automatic you declarator the endpoint, the same for API Provider only with default setup, but with multiple routing, no impossible, I did all possibilities that you can image.

Basically in all target points, in the target endpoint police, the pre-flow, you must add this function:

//Routing mechanism
function RoutingCpiEndpoint() {
    
var suffix = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
if (suffix == null) {
    suffix = "";
}

var targetBase = "<SAP CPI ADDRESS>";

// Use the + operator for compatibility
var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + suffix.toString();

// Set it back to a context variable so the target can use it
context.setVariable("target.url", finalUrl);

}

Figure 12 - Adding the magic java script in the Target End point - Pre flow - Incoming Message of each Iflow

After that you can see the debug in SAP APIM:

Figure 13 - Debug all policies - Proxy Endpoint - Target Endpoint - Pre/Pos Flow

Variables from the debug:

Figure 14 - Debug variables runtime

Postman test:

Figure 15 - Postman

By adopting this design, you eliminate the need to build individual proxies for every endpoint. This centralizes policy management, keeps the SAP API Management cockpit clutter-free, and creates a highly organized, scalable architecture that is significantly easier to govern.

Figure 16 - One API proxy vs Individual Proxy

The Consumer Perspective:

By adopting this approach, SAP API Management (APIM) serves as a centralized "Mega Proxy." This allows for the reutilization of a single entry point to deliver multiple services to various consumers. These consumers can access diverse SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) APIs, which handle data mapping, transformation, and complex business logic for back-end systems like SAP ECC, SAP S/4HANA (both on-premise and cloud), and other third-party services.

In this architecture, SAP APIM acts as a robust API Firewall. No direct CPI endpoints are exposed to the consumer, effectively shielding your landscape from cyberattacks and unauthorized access.

Figure 17 - Consumer perspective

The Final Whistle: Game, Set, Match.

And there you have it! You‚Äôve just turned a potential "Proxy Nightmare" into a sleek, centralized, routing machine.

While others are out there manually building their 157th individual proxy (and crying into their coffee), you‚Äôre sitting back with a clean cockpit, a single "Mega-Proxy," and a architecture that actually scales. We took the 404 monster, hit it with a bit of JavaScript magic, and walked away with the Checkmate.

Go ahead, deploy it, and watch your monitoring dashboard finally look like it was managed by a pro. Just don't tell everyone the "Checkmate" secret at once‚Äîlet them wonder how you became an APIM wizard overnight.

Kind Regards,

Viana

References about topic:

In this blog, the author presents a different approach using query parameters, and while it is a valid perspective, I found it difficult to identify how to call different endpoints specifically, also editing manually the xml's, not sure if in 2021 the APIM version required such manual intervention..

SAPAPIM - Guide to create single API Proxy with multiple Target End Point and capability to change the target URI during execution

entry.title: Using SCIM API for User & Member List management in SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve worked with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you might have come across the SCIM 2.0‚Äìcompliant API. This API is designed for managing users and member lists, following the common specification.
Now, SCIM is a broad standard with many optional elements. SAP‚Äôs implementation focuses on the essentials, so not every optional detail is covered - but everything you need for user and list management is there. 

Where does this SCIM API fit in the Work Zone landscape?

The SCIM API is utilized by SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) to handle User and List/Group management for the Digital Workplace Service component of both following variants- Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition and SuccessFactors Work Zone. 

If you‚Äôre configuring IPS for Work Zone user provisioning, you‚Äôll find detailed guidance in our help documentation.

  • Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
  • SuccessFactors Work Zone

IPS should always be used as the primary means of User provisioning & management in Work Zone.
But what if you want to go hands-on with the API yourself, for small scale user data adjustment or simply to check data? That is what we are going to cover in this blog.

Important resource to go through before attempting to use the API-> Using the SCIM API | SAP Help Portal

Key elements needed to use the SCIM API for User & List Management-

  • Digital Workplace/Jam URL-> Administration Console -> Overview -> Custom Domain URL (for Jam instances not using custom domain, just the regular JAM DC URL- jamX.sapjam.com)
  • SCIM API Client Key: Administration Console -> OAuth Clients -> SCIM Client (will have integration URL as  http://www.simplecloud.info) -> Key
  • SCIM API Client Secret: Administration Console -> OAuth Clients -> SCIM Client (will have integration URL as  http://www.simplecloud.info) -> Secret
  • SCIM API Token URL-> https://<Digital Workplace/Jam URL>/api/v1/auth/token

 

[A] GETTING THE SCIM API ACCESS TOKEN

First step in using SCIM API is getting the access token.

Using any suitable tool (like Postman) POST call needs to be made to the SCIM API Token URL, passing the SCIM API Client Key & Secret. This will return the Access token.

Steps (Postman tool used for this example):

  1. Method: POST
  2. URL: https://<Digital Workplace/Jam URL>/api/v1/auth/token
  3. In the request Body:
    • client_id: < SCIM API Client Key >
    • client_secret: < SCIM API Client Secret >
    • grant_type: client_credentials
  4. Here is what the API call looks like in Postman-
  5. After making the call by hitting ‚ÄúSend‚Äù, access token returned in Response-

 

[B] USING THE SCIM API TO VIEW, UPDATE OR DELETE USER

User management via SCIM API will require-

  • Access Token: from section [A] steps
  • User_UUID: Can be grabbed from the browser URL of any user profile page in Work Zone. The alphanumeric identifier at the end of the URL will be the UUid.
    • Example URL: https://swzhrcpsdemo.workzonehr.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com/site#workzone-profile?sap-app-origin-hint=&/profile/wall/QljGDtyuvpRDK7epwV0GiU
    • QljGDtyuvpRDK7epwV0GiUis the UUid.
  • SCIM User API URL: https://<Digital Workplace/Jam URL>/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>

Using the above User API URL and the User UUid,

  • GET calls can be made to view user data.
  • PUT calls can be made to update user data.
  • DELETE calls can be made to delete any user from Work Zone database.

 

[B.1] TO VIEW ANY USER RECORD

  1. Method: GET
  2. URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>
  3. In the request Header,
    •      Authorization = OAuth <access_token>
  4. Here is what the API call looks like in Postman for one example User UUid:
  5. And the Response after hitting ‚ÄúSend‚Äù

[B.2] TO UPDATE ANY USER RECORD

  1. Method: PUT
  2. URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>
  3. In the request Header,
    •      Authorization = OAuth <access_token>
  4. In the request Body, user data request payload in DWS/Jam SCIM format.
  5. Here is what the API call looks like for one example User-
  6. If we submit this API call by hitting ‚ÄúSend‚Äù, the user will get updated with the payload data from the request body.

[B.3] TO DELETE ANY USER RECORD

  1. Method: DELETE
  2. URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>
  3. In the request Header,
    •      Authorization = OAuth <access_token>
  4. Here is what the API call looks like for one example User UUid:
  5. If we submit this API call by hitting ‚ÄúSend‚Äù, the user will get deleted

 

[C] USING THE SCIM API TO VIEW OR DELETE MEMBER LIST

  • Access Token: from section [A] steps
  • list_name: Name of the List
  • list_id: Has to be retrieved via API call, searching with List Name.
  • SCIM List API URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups/<list_id>

[C.1] GET THE LIST ID

To search List ID for any List, same steps to be followed as viewing users, [B.1] section above, only changing to API endpoint /Groups:

  • URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups? filter=displayName eq "<list_name>"

The API response will have the List ID in ‚Äúid‚Äù field

[C.2] VIEW A LIST

To view SCIM data for any List, same steps to be followed as viewing users, [B.1] section above, only changing to API endpoint /Groups:

  • URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups/< list_id >

[C.3] DELETE A LIST

To delete any List, same steps to be followed as deleting users, [B.3] section above, only changing to API endpoint /Groups:

  • URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups/< list_id >

entry.title: Re: CBO Transported to TEST but Not Available in Business...
entry.content:
Dear @MohamedKharbouch,

Question 1. Is this behavior expected?

It can be expected if you transported only the CBO definition but not the related Custom Catalog Extension / IAM / launchpad artifacts. SAP explicitly calls out that when a CBO-generated app isn‚Äôt available in the target tenant, common causes are:

  • the app wasn‚Äôt added to a business catalog via Custom Catalog Extensions or
  • the custom catalog extension wasn‚Äôt transported even though the CBO was

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2544054

Question 2. Do business catalog assignments have to be re-done manually per system?

No, not if you transport the right artifacts. The assignment that matters for Key User Extensibility is typically stored as a Custom Catalog Extensions for CBOs you‚Äôll often see an entry with the _SCBO suffix. SAP guidance for CBO access is to maintain it in Custom Catalog Extensions and publish it

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2687424

If that Custom Catalog Extensions and related IAM objects wasn‚Äôt included in the export/import then yes you would end up re-doing it manually in TEST but that‚Äôs more of a workaround than a best practice

Question 3. Recommended sequence

In DEV:

1. CBO is Published and Generated UI exists if that‚Äôs what you want to expose

2. Go to Custom Catalog Extensions:

    • Search your CBO and open the entry with suffix _SCBO
    • Add the required standard business catalog
    • Publish and run Check
      IMPORTANT: SAP notes exports can fail / behave inconsistently if the catalog extension or assigned catalogs are not published

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3407810

3. When building the Software Collection ensure you include not only the CBO but also the catalog/IAM artifacts

SAP even lists the typical missing transport objects for custom app not visible after transport scenarios:

  • Business catalog (SIA6)
  • IAM app (SIA1)
  • Business Catalog Assignment (SIA7)
  • Launchpad Descriptor Item (UIAD)

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3635471

In TEST:

  1. Open Custom Catalog Extensions and search for the YY1_<‚Ä¶>_SCBO entry:
    • If it‚Äôs there but shows Unpublished, publish it and re-check
  2. Be aware publishing can be asynchronous after import. SAP explicitly mentions cases where it‚Äôs transported but not finished publishing yet and the fix is to wait until status becomes Published

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2788116

3. If the _SCBO entry is missing entirely that strongly indicates the catalog extension and/or related IAM objects simply weren‚Äôt transported, re-export/re-import with the missing objects included

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2544054

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Applicant's Phone Number in Recruiting
entry.content:
Hello,

entry.title: Re: Plant (WERKS) - Company Code (BUKRS) relationship. The easy way, please!
entry.content:
üëãüèºHi @Lakshmipathi! That‚Äôs not necessarily true all the time. Although it is a common practice to assign the same value to both Plant (WERKS) and Valuation Area (BWKEY), SAP Developers must never assume it will be always set it in that way. That‚Äôs why SAP implemented Primary and Foreign Keys in most of its tables, but that, that‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶ It is not the purpose of this discussion to give a lecture on Database Normalization.
Last but not least, SAP Development best practices encourages Developers to avoid accessing directly database tables and use CDS Views/CDS View Entities instead. 
I hope my answer helped you.
Thank you for joining this discussion!

entry.title: Retrospective 2025: SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Since the official launch at Sapphire 2025, SAP Enterprise Service Management has rapidly transformed enterprise service delivery for customers. The unified platform simplifies IT landscapes, cuts costs, boosts productivity, and removes hours spent by employees searching for experts and back-and-forth email threads to find an answer to a business inquiry.  With AI- powered employee self-service and a unified service agent workspace including contextual summaries & recommendations, democratized knowledge, and process automation, the result for all are faster resolutions and higher productivity that drive measurable bottom-line improvements. Let‚Äôs explore SAP ESM‚Äôs 2025 journey.

SAP Solution Integration Accelerates Time-to-Value

SAP Enterprise Service Management delivers integration with SAP Cloud ERP applications accelerating time‚Äëto‚Äëvalue by eliminating system silos and enabling unified, efficient service experiences. This connectivity turns cross‚Äëfunctional processes into rapid, measurable business outcomes‚Äîreducing resolution steps and time.

HR Service Delivery - SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central integration delivers AI enabled self-service and agent-assisted service. Both employees and service professionals have a seamless, one stop experience in getting quick resolutions to their inquiries, including immediate AI-led answers. Knowledge democratization from multiple source solutions ensuring accurate responses and high efficiency.  See more about SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management here.

Financial Shared Service and more‚Ä¶ - SAP Cloud ERP integration provides supplier and business partner master data and business document integration -  financial support processes such as invoice inquires, dispute management, accrual postings and payment advice inquiries are resolved with ease. This integration additionally supports deployments of use cases with other SAP software solution areas such as:  financial management,  supply chain and spend management .

Additionally, with the ease of business configuration and no-code extensibility, SAP Enterprise Service Management customers easily expand to support needs in other areas such as partner management, security and compliance as well as people and culture topics.

Shared foundation with SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud

Within SAP CX, the ease of extending internal support use cases to sales and service is central to SAP Enterprise Service Management. With a shared technical foundation, deployment time and IT landscape management effort is reduced - eliminating data replication and inconsistency, ensuring a uniform approach to service management across the enterprise. Here are some valuable support scenarios enabled by SAP Enterprise Service Management in Sales and Service:

Sales Support scenarios with SAP Sales Cloud delivers quick internal support helping salespeople reduce their administrative load and focus on customer engagement and strategy.  Support scenarios help salespeople access essential market intel, financial data, and collaborative resources from marketing, finance, and other departments, enabling them to target the right buyers, tailor value propositions, and hit their quotas efficiently. Deal desk support further expedites approvals, and provides timely guidance on complex deals supporting efficient deal cycles.

Complex Customer Service Support scenarios that start with a customer inquiry in SAP Service Cloud may require expert support from back-office experts to facilitate resolution are easily routed to the right resource for quick resolution. A ticket/case created in SAP Service Cloud can be assigned to an enterprise service agent for extended support, collaboration or direct response such as product quality complaint, dispute or financial questions.

Delivering Human & AI Efficiency - Select Innovation Highlights 2025:

In 2025, SAP Enterprise Service Management delivered a new wave of innovations focused on maximizing human and AI-led efficiency to help remove friction in service delivery processes.  Our unified, AI-enriched workspace connects employees with instant answers, the right experts and streamlines handoffs to ensure consistent, measurable productivity gains and cost savings. These capabilities turn insight into action, making work simpler, faster, and more effective for employees.

Here are few highlights in review:

Responsive mobile interface for Self-Service - A mobile-optimized interface and embedded self-service widget lets employees create, view, and manage support cases. A business user defined, contextual form-based entry is completed by the employee on any portal or device. This improves access and data accuracy, boosts self-service adoption, reduces assisted service workload, and speeds resolution times‚Äîdriving higher productivity and better employee experience.

Joule with SAP Enterprise Service Management - Enabling service agents to have customer, supplier, and employee information at their fingertips. Leveraging generative AI capabilities, Joule aims to understand requests, retrieve information and complete tasks in a conversational way. Service agents easily interact with Joule and improve productivity.

 Multi-Document Action Handling in Business Documents - Business document extraction has now been extended to enable bulk updates and lookups across multiple documents in one step showing and activating actions based on configurable business rules.

Automating Actions in Business Documents - Using the business document designer, you can add automation rules to trigger actions automatically based on specific conditions. These automated interactions easily extent to external/3rd party systems using predefined API mappings for ‚Äòpost‚Äô and ‚Äòlookup‚Äô action types. This feature reduces the need for manual intervention and improves agent productivity enabling more time to focus on value-add activities.

Instant Learning Support in Document Extraction - AI-led document extraction has been extended to learn from service agent feedback ensuring higher quality extraction results and use of the best model to suit the need. This requires no manual model training and provides instant improvement enabling faster processing times, fewer corrections and improved automation of document workflows helping teams work more efficiently and reducing operational costs.

First Level Case Categorization with Business Information Extraction - Achieve immediate operational efficiency and increased accuracy using business information extraction for first level case categorization enabling quick time to value from AI-driven case categorization. Based on the case subject and description, the LLM model classifies it under one of the matching category values from the ones configured in grouping or class.

 

Visit the SAP Discovery Center for more information on SAP Enterprise Service Management base and premium AI capabilities.

Delivering the Win: Unified platform, high adoption, cross‚Äëdepartment connectivity

For customers like D√∂hler experiencing tremendous productivity gains by expanding SAP Enterprise Service Management into multiple scenarios across their organization, the value of a harmonized enterprise service management approach is clear.  Read about their story here. But, its not just SAP customers that are seeing tremendous value ‚Äì SAP is also deploying SAP Enterprise Service Management expanding our footprint by 5X throughout 2025 ‚Äì from 250 agents in our global learning support team serving over 2 million customers,  including employees, vendors, partners and customers, to well over 1200 agents by year end spanning a wide range of use cases within HR, finance and people and culture ‚Äì with more to come in 2026!

Moving Ahead to 2026

SAP Enterprise Service Management had an outstanding 2025‚Äîdelivering a CX‚Äëled, cross‚ÄëLoB solution to SAP customers around the globe. A huge thanks to the dedicated cross‚ÄëLoB and cross‚Äëfunctional SAP teams who brought deep expertise, drove rapid growth and value-add solution advancements, and nurtured and enabled a broad ecosystem providing support across the board. From inception in 2024 to launch and throughout the year, it has been an exciting journey. Further, we are grateful to our partners and customers for embracing SAP Service Management. Your early inputs and feedback shaped high‚Äëvalue capabilities and roadmap priorities.

Looking to 2026, we‚Äôll build on this momentum with new and expanded content packages designed to increase value and further accelerate deployments - stay tuned for upcoming release details and success stories.

Thank you to all - SAP colleagues, our partners, and our customers for making 2025 a success! For more on SAP CX highlights from the year, see our year‚Äëin‚Äëreview blogs:

SAP Service Cloud

SAP Emarsys

SAP Sales Cloud (coming soon)

SAP Commerce (coming Soon)

Wishing our community and colleagues a healthy, prosperous, and adventurous New Year!

entry.title: Re: Use of Assignment and Reference Number in Copy Control
entry.content: Yes if the sales order has a PO number but the Assignment and Reference fields are blank, the PO number can still flow into the accounting document depending on how copy control (VTFL) is configured. The system uses the values defined in VTFL only when the originating document does not supply them. Recommended practice is to align these fields with your reconciliation and reporting needs: typically, the Reference Number is used for customer PO tracking, while the Assignment Number supports grouping and clearing in FI.

entry.title: Re: Partner TDD with new IAS/IPS
entry.content:
Hello @ayakaHA 

Thank you for your question

Here is a quick summary on your question:

Regarding IAS: yes you can use a separate IAS tenant for your new TDD tenant but you will have to order additional SAP tenant plan rather than creating it yourself inside S4H. See Get Your Tenant and https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/tenant-model-and-licensing for more details.

For IPS, the standard is to have one for your tests environment one Prod. You normally do not need to buy a new IPS as a standalone service because they seem not to be available any longer. See KBA 3405942 for more insights.

So, what i recommend for IPS is to, reuse your existing IPS test bundle tenant and add the new TDD S4H tenant as an additional target system inside your IPS tenant, instead of trying to get a new IPS tenant.

If you truly need a third IPS tenant, then you can send a request to SAP.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom logic for migrating for migrating information...
entry.content:
Dear @c_walid,

Badi code runs only if your enhancement is assigned to a routine number and that routine number is assigned in copy control for the relevant billing flow.

1. Open SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC)

2. Run Define Custom Routines for Data Transfer to Billing Documents (102865)

    • Create a Routine Number
    • Assign your Enhancement ID, your Custom Logic implementation of SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER to that routine number.

3. Assign the routine number to Copying Control for your proces:

    • Sales Order and Billing Document or
    • Delivery and Billing Document, depending on how you generate invoices

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4603118feda9495892abadbe8f8c3d14/a7a8635e08694ebdaa48620fa9c2f89c.html

I have recreated your requirements in my environment, below are the assumptions:

  • I created customfield (YY1_DADA) on BP

 

  • I created MyField (YY1_MyField) on Billing Document

 

  • In customfield on BP I put it in value below:

 

  • I used a Badi: SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER with code below:

 

"--- Mandatory step for all implementations:

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc           TO bil_doc_res.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item      TO bil_doc_item_res.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item_contr TO bil_doc_item_contr_res.

 

"--- Transfer BP custom field -> Billing Document custom field (Header)

DATA lv_bp    TYPE i_businesspartner-businesspartner.

DATA lv_dada  TYPE i_businesspartner-yy1_dada_bus.

 

lv_bp = |{ bil_doc-soldtoparty ALPHA = IN }|.

 

IF lv_bp IS NOT INITIAL AND bil_doc_res-yy1_myfield_bdh IS INITIAL.

 

  SELECT SINGLE yy1_dada_bus

    FROM i_businesspartner

    WHERE businesspartner = @lv_bp

    INTO @lv_dada.

 

  IF sy-subrc = 0 AND lv_dada IS NOT INITIAL.

    bil_doc_res-yy1_myfield_bdh = lv_dada.

  ENDIF.

 

ENDIF.

 

  • Badi transfer value from Master Data to Billing Document

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Billing indicator mapping configuration in sap JVA
entry.content:
Hello Kaustubh,

Below are some details which might be helpful to you.

Billing Indicator Mapping in SAP Joint Venture Accounting is a foundational configuration used to determine how financial postings are treated during Joint Interest Billing. Since standard FI and CO postings do not explicitly indicate whether a cost or revenue should be billed to joint venture partners, SAP uses this mapping to derive billing relevance based on predefined rules.

The configuration evaluates the posting source through object types such as G/L accounts, cost elements, and transaction types, along with defined account ranges and settlement contexts. Based on this evaluation, a billing indicator is assigned, which governs whether the item is included in billing, excluded, netted, or treated as overhead or revenue.

During JIB processing, the billing indicator drives extraction, netting, and partner billing behavior. Incorrect or incomplete mappings are a common root cause of billing discrepancies, such as costs not appearing in JIB or settlements being billed incorrectly. Following best practices and maintaining well-structured, documented mappings ensures accurate partner billing and compliance with joint venture agreements.

 

TopicExplanation
PurposeBilling Indicator Mapping determines whether FI/CO postings are billable, non-billable, nettable, overhead, revenue, or excluded during Joint Interest Billing (JIB).
Business NeedFI/CO documents do not inherently contain billing relevance; this mapping converts accounting attributes into JIB billing logic.
Configuration ObjectBilling Indicator Mapping
Transaction CodeGJVL
SPRO PathSAP IMG ‚Üí Financial Accounting ‚Üí Joint Venture Accounting ‚Üí Joint Interest Billing ‚Üí Define Billing Indicator Mapping
Object TypeIdentifies the source of posting such as G/L Account (GL), Cost Element (CE), or Transaction Type (TT).
Account / Cost Element RangeDefines the nature of cost or revenue and drives the assignment of billing indicators.
Transaction TypeDifferentiates primary postings from settlements or assessments and prevents incorrect billing of secondary costs.
Billing IndicatorThe derived output that controls JIB behavior (e.g., BILL, NBIL, NET, OH, REV, EXCL).
Indicator Derivation LogicDuring JIB extraction, SAP evaluates object type, account or cost element range, and transaction type to assign a billing indicator.
JIB Processing ImpactBilling indicator controls extraction, netting, partner billing, and partner statements.
FI/CO Posting RequirementsDocument must contain Joint Venture and Equity Group for JIB relevance.
ExampleCost Element 410000 (Drilling Cost) mapped with Object Type CE and Billing Indicator BILL results in partner billing.
Common IssuesMissing mappings, incorrect object type, broad account ranges, or missing transaction types for settlements.
Troubleshooting ApproachAnalyze FI document ‚Üí Identify account/cost element ‚Üí Verify transaction type ‚Üí Check GJVL mapping ‚Üí Confirm billing indicator.
Best PracticeSeparate primary and secondary cost elements, maintain transaction types for settlements, avoid broad ranges, and document billing rules.
Governance & ControlRegular review of mappings aligned with joint operating agreements reduces billing disputes and audit risks.

If you find my response helpful, share your feedback. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your support.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Can i set a cookie for sap websites in order to login...
entry.content:
We offer the Single Sign-On (SSO) with SAP Passports feature, which enables you to access a wide range of SAP websites without entering your S-user ID and password, while ensuring the secure transmission of your data.

Once you apply for an SAP Passport via SAP for Me, the SAP Trust Center will issue your digital SAP Passport. This credential serves as a secure link between your local computer access permissions and your SAP for Me access credentials. With this in place, you no longer need to enter your user ID and password when accessing designated SAP websites.

For further details, please refer to the SAP Knowledge Base Article:1296615 - How to apply for and install the SAP Passport browser certificate - SAP for Me
